queue.fact_text: On December 31, 1992, Czechoslovakia dissolved without a shot fired, splitting into the Czech Republic and Slovakia in what became known as the Velvet Divorce. It was a rare example of a multinational state gently agreeing to become two, more clearly defined homes.

episode.title: Morning Drops #11 - Mediterranean Boat

queue.fact_text: On the last day of 1968, the Soviet-built Tupolev Tu-144 took its first flight, beating Concorde to become the world’s first civilian supersonic airliner. For a brief moment, it turned the idea of crossing continents faster than sound from science fiction into scheduled service.

queue.fact_text: In 1670, after secretly probing Spanish defenses along the Chilean coast, the English expedition led by John Narborough slipped out of Corral Bay on December 31. Four of his men, sent ashore under a flag of truce, were seized and never returned, vanishing into the machinery of colonial rivalries.

episode.title: Morning Drops #20 - Hitchhiking Poland

queue.fact_text: On December 31, 406, waves of Vandals, Alans, and Suebi tribes crossed a frozen Rhine, surging into Roman Gaul. The river that had long been a frontier turned, for one winter night, into a solid bridge that accelerated the unraveling of the Western Roman Empire.

queue.fact_text: On the last day of 1999, the United States formally handed control of the Panama Canal and its surrounding zone to Panama, honoring treaties signed in 1977. A century-old emblem of American engineering and power became a reclaimed artery in the hands of a much smaller nation.

queue.fact_text: On New Year’s Eve 1994, Russian forces launched a brutal assault on Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, in a bid to crush separatism. The urban battle that followed turned entire neighborhoods into rubble and showed how modern war could swallow a city street by street.

queue.fact_text: By the end of 1947, the Cold War had begun, and on December 31, 1951, the Marshall Plan formally concluded its mission to rebuild Western Europe. queue.fact_text: NASA’s GRAIL mission, which achieved lunar orbit on December 31, 2011, used two nearly identical spacecraft playing a cosmic game of follow-the-leader around the Moon. By measuring tiny changes in their distance as they flew over mountains, basins, and hidden structures, scientists effectively 'weighed' the lunar crust from orbit.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.
